title: strip led holder for anet a8 extruder group

description.text:
below this english text

Questo è uno dei miei primi oggetti 3d, forse può essere perfezionato? forse, lo lascio come è per il vostro spasso.
È stampato con un anet a8, di serie.
L'ho interamente creato con tinkercad dopo aver visto molte alternative sul web e specialmente qui.
I binari tengono la striscia (solo 3 led), i due fori all'estremità servono per fermare la striscia e il suo cavo di alimentazione con una fascetta per cavi.
I due mozzi posteriori sono da inserire nei fori nella parte posteriore dell'estrusore che non sono filettati.
Il consumo energetico è di circa 1 mA, quindi puoi collegarlo alle alimentazioni a basso consumo senza timore.

Qualsiasi tipo di suggerimento è benvenuto.

This is one of my early 3d objects, maybe it can be perfected ? maybe, I leave it as is for your delight.
It's printed with a anet a8 just out of the box.
I've entirely created it with tinkercad after watched a lot of alternatives around web and expecially here.
The rails hold the strip (just 3 leds), the two holes at end are for stop the strip and his power cable with a tiny cable tie.
The two stubs on rear are for plug their in the holes on extruder's rear that aren't threaded.
The power consumption is around 1 mA, so you can plug it on low power PSU's without any fear.

Any kind of suggestions are welcome.

author: iw9hlv

title: Replicator Front Cover Stabilizer Brackets & Lift Handles

description.text:
These are designed for drandolph's "3mm hood and cover" thingiverse.com/thing:23386
I found during certain printing operations the cover would move back and forth making a flapping sound which became very annoying.  So I designed the stabilizer brackets.  I also found the front cover hard to remove after I put the stabilizer brackets on, so I designed lift handles which clip onto the lower alignment slot.
Both of these objects are designed with a .75mm width to space the front cover evenily and are a perfect match with the "Replicator Cover Hanger Bolt Spacers v2" thingiverse.com/thing:27223

Printed using .27 layer height, 100% infill (solid), 1 shell. Using Replicator 5.5 but with default speeds (printing small objects like this with acceleration I find melts the previous layer too much). Printed without a raft Ensure you measure your filament to have a tight fit. The stabilizer brackets may not fit if your plywood has swelled or shunk from humidity. My replicator is in a room that sits around 45%-55% humidity and these fit quite snug. Original Tinkercad objects:
https://tinkercad.com/things/3iEpPAJ1kkB-replicator-front-cover-stabilizer-brackets https://tinkercad.com/things/9nR1xBnnXQ6-replicator-front-cover-lift-handles V2 of the lift handles has a larger "dimples" sticking out the back (old one was 3mm X 3mm x 2mm.. this one is 4.5mm x 4.5mm x 3mm). I also made the front front/back sections 1mm taller. The dimple location has been moved slightly as well. MUCH tighter fit:
https://tinkercad.com/things/iCxNfl9ilj5-replicator-front-cover-lift-handles-v2 V2 of of the stabilizer bracket has dimples sticking out the back clip. These are 3mm x .5mm. I haven't printed these.
https://tinkercad.com/things/kG29YButXCR-replicator-front-cover-stabilizer-brackets-v2

comments.text: Hi, can you please add "grip knobs" to the stabilizer brackets so that they grip the Makerbot? They tend to fall off a lot when I remove the front cover.
comments.author: iceberg

comments.text: Yes I've seen those. I did not add them as I never had an issue.  However I've added v2 with 3mm x .5mm dimples.
comments.author: iceberg

comments.text: Neat!  I've wanted this exact thing since I got my hood kit.
comments.author: DocRayStantz

comments.text: Saw your pic!  But I think you have the clips reversed!  They should sit level (the dimple sticking out the back is off-set for that)

title: DC-17 Hand Blaster (Authentic Phase I Animated Version)

description.text:
The authentic Clone Wars DC-17 blaster pistol animated version (Phase I) !

Accuracy model with all parts and details designed from several references, to comply to the original LucasArts design.
Designed to be printed and assembled easily.

# SPECS #

 Total dimensions [mm] : 260 x 167 x 52
 Maximum cuted part dimension : 200mm
 Parts number : 10 (9 different)

Other parts needed :

  • Spring Ø4mm (x1)
  • M4 Screws (x2)

for LED using only :

  • Blue color LED Ø5 (x1)
  • Small electric wires (30 cm)
  • 75 ohm resistor (x1)
  • Spring Ø4-8 (x1)
  • Spring Ø4 (x1)
  • Paperclip (x1)
  • Aluminum foil

Thanks to like, comment or share this model to support me !
Feel free to share your opinion about it and ask your questions, you can also propose me some modifications ...
Don't forget to share your making !!! ;P

Les français, n'hésitez pas à commenter je pourrai vous répondre ! ;)

i3 MK2S

No

Notes:

Supports are only needed on part 3 ("3_Corps_Pièce_3"), the other parts can be printed without support easily !
Raft and brim are not necessary but can be used if your print bed adherence is limited.
Can be printed from 5% to 100% infill (more infill gives a more realistic rendering).

Designed on SolidWorks 2016 with official references !

I used official Star Wars - The Clone Wars pictures to design this famous blaster pistol, the main blaster used by Clone Captain Rex !

Captain Rex in Phase II armor, holding his two DC-17 Handguns Captain Keeli in Phase I armor, holding DC-17 Handguns Captain Rex in Phase II armor, holding a DC-17 Handgun

• 3D Preview : https://sketchfab.com/models/0838eba3e3ec45ce9341b2c00b78428a

  • Assembly animation : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8pbqZW09n9E&t=3s

Commercial version available, two simple solutions to get it :

  • 1) Make me a $7 donation with PayPal (please contact me on Thingiverse in this case)

  • 2) Buy it for $14.99 on Turbosquid.com (available soon)
Contents :

  • STL / OBJ formats : All 9 non-engraved parts in high quality mesh (more triangles)

  • SolidWorks format : Original SolidWorks pistol design (.sldprt / .sldasm) to modify completely all the components

  • IGES format : All parts in IGES (.igs) format to modify them easily

Designed on my own : Jetstorm_477

If you like this blaster, you can let me know it crediting me ! You'll just have to follow this simple paypal link and choose the amount ;P

Thanks a lot by advance, enjoy !

author: justsean

title: Star Wars Imperial Snowflake (BlocksCAD Snowflake Challenge)

description.text: This is the second snowflake I have designed for this contest. I decided to use a Star Wars theme, and the Imperial insignia lends itself very well to a snowflake with its six-pronged design. Some features like the eyes of the troopers, the tops of their helmets, and the inner details of the insignia are made with the Text tool instead of shapes (the eyes are commas, the top of the helmets are closed parentheses, and the inside of the insignia is made with apostrophes). I have no idea if this is easily printable since I don't have a printer to test it on, but I tried my best to be creative with what the BlocksCAD tool gave me to work with. I also annotated all of the blocks in the rotate loop so it it easy to figure out what does what.

This little tank is designed to allow my students to prototype their robotic ideas.

It has some significant improvements over my previous versions of tracked robots.

Making use of 22mm skateboard bearings, improved ground clearance and greater track flexibility, this little bot can move confidently over a wide range of terrain.

It is designed to be able to be printed on a printer >= 120mm (although if you sacrifice the top shelf you can print it in an Up! Mini)

There are a number of different versions of this tank to come out, with this first one designed for prototyping in the classroom. It runs off a Tamiya 70097 Twin-Motor Gearbox Kit, but the rest of the electronics are up to you. In the video linked below it is running with a Raspberry Pi Zero W and some Pololu motor drivers and power converters.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VD7uiKfXYNM

PLEASE READ THE PRINT AND ASSEMBLY GUIDE CAREFULLY BEFORE PRINTING
(This is the PDF in the "Thing Files")

Please note - I cannot share with you the source CAD Files

Part List:
24 x 10mm (or 9mm) M3 Screws
28 x M3 Nuts
8 x 30mm M3 Standoffs
8 x 22mm Skateboard Bearings (8mm bore, 7mm thick)
1 x Tamiya 70097 Twin-Motor Gearbox Kit (Set up in 203:1 Gear Ratio)

At 45x63mm it fits into the standard nitro bottle for refueling (at least my one).
Has a small vent for air-back-flow at the side.
My first creation for 3D-printing.
I used ABS, it does not dissolve in nitro. I don't think PLA does, but not tested.

title: Nerf Modulus Recon MkII Carbon Fiber Arms

description.text:
Original design by Scrutmonkey. I had some 6mm carbon tube lying around and thought that carbon tubes on my Nerf would look cool. Note that these are ends for the push arms only. You will still need the barrel and pump grip from the original creators. I remixed the arm ends to accommodate the carbon tubes, mostly for the geometry of how it connects to the pump grip, as the rear connector and arm length are perfect from the original. Might also work on a retaliator but that would need different length arms and I don't have one to test.

You will need:
2 M4 8mm Bolts
2 original flat screws that attached the pump OR 2 PC chassis screws
2 6mm external diameter carbon rod tubes, each 93mm long
Glue or epoxy to permanently bond the arms to the ends.

title: Ceiling Light Fixture Vent
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a vent for the common 10in round lights found all over the United States. I wanted to use some new LED bulbs in my living room. They burnt out much faster than anticipated. After removing them I realized the base of the bulbs were cracked. They are not intended to be in enclosed fixtures. I wasn't going back to my old incandescent bulbs, so I made this vent.

You need to print the model 3 times to create the 10 in circle. The light fixture I have came with a spacer that was 3/4 tall. I no longer use the spacer because this vent is just about that height. I have only just implemented my design, I hope it will resolve my issue... if not, at least it looks cool!

Notes:

This model has 60 degree overhangs inside the hexagons, if you need supports, use them. I had one of my prints fail (you need three to complete the circle) due to warping where the nozzle took out some of the thinner portions.

I used Cura as a slicer.

Installation

Set three of these atop your light cover grooved side down. Lift into position and tighten the threaded ball or nut that comes with your fixture. (you can stow the spacer inside the light if you like.) Finished.

Solidworks

description.text:
I printed the E3DV6 mounting parts by carstenheuer(https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2282071) and a new x-axis plate (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2753267) but needed a mount for my bed sensor. I started with the one by Karl_FLG(https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2065355), and extended it to clear the fan duct- my sensor requires the 17mm version, while the original one appeared to have a 13mm hole for the sensor.

So after actually printing this and doing my switch over to e3d v6.. with a detour over a bricked main board.. I got it all put together and realized that the sensor mount would hit the frame when the x-carriage ran to the endstop.. so I redesigned the one with the larger hole- turned out 17mm was too tight as well- so I removed the first 2 attempts and uploaded the final product.

The offset for Marlin for the level sensor is -46x and -11y

2018.02.02 after using 2mm screws the first time through, I decided to redesign for 3mm screws- the holes are 3.1mm- I'm also attaching the x-axis plate and e3dv6 mount that are desiged for 3mm screws. the e3dv6 mount has 4.3mm holes to hold uxcell 3mm heat set threaded inserts (https://www.amazon.com/uxcell-Female-Knurled-Threaded-Embedment/dp/B01IYWTCWW/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1517620867&sr=8-1&keywords=uxcell+3mm+heat+set+threaded+inserts)
the e3d mount needs to be rotated to print with the fan side down- the sensor mount needs to be rotated 180 to lay flat on the bed- you should be able to do this in your slicer- I will try to do it in the original stl's when I have a chance.

description.text:
Fits on the front of a Nerf Rapidstrike trimmed as per fit guide here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bTH47Upl6CU

Test fit, then glue halves to shell with your choice of plastic adhesive. I recommend Devcon Plastic Welder.

description.text:
base para lúminaria
utilizado abs em 225º
FEITO EM ABS 225º
it's high noon

The Tantalus cup works normally if it is partially filled.  If filled to the brim most of the liquid siphons out through the bottom.  It is also called a  Pythagorean cup.
Thing:17330 by Scooter46290 is a such a cup with a simple but elegant siphon composed of three concentric cones about a central tube.  Here is another version where the siphon is concealed in the stem.  It has the advantage that the siphon has a greater head and can more completely empty the cup.   Open scad and stl files are provided.

There was a leakage problem in early versions.  The siphon always worked well.  The problem occured when the cup was partially filled.  Liquid leaked through the wall of the central stem and slowly trickled out the bottom.
Printing with 100% infill, one shell, and 0.2 mm layer height solved the problem.  Playing the gcode files in netfabb Studio was helpful in deciding which parameters to use.
On my Replicator the cup takes a bit under 3 hours to print using 100% infill, one shell, and 0.2 mm layer height.  It was printed directly on the build platform.

comments.text:
If the siphon was in the wall (on the side you drink from) then when
you take a sip the water level always rises above the point on which the
siphon starts working(since you tilt the container, perhaps it's better
to say you lower the point at which the siphon works). If the whole
wall was connected no vacuum would be created but it would still leak.
If the siphons were divided into small sections those would then work
even after you stop taking a sip, which could still be fun but not
really the same...
closer to the real torment of Tantalus though.

title: Pixel 2 Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I modified my basic protective case for the Google Pixel 2 with a hexagon cutout pattern, inspired by Screwyluie's XL design.

The case is designed for a secure snap fit around the corners, while still being relatively easy to remove. I've left wide cutouts around the power and volume buttons so they remain easily accessible, and a wider cutout around the USB C port to accommodate my USB C headphones' over-sized plug.

The case shell is 1.2mm thick

I've included STL, SLDPRT (SolidWorks) and STEP files of the design, at least one of which should be compatible with most CAD software for editing.

Printer:

FolgerTech 2020 Prusia i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed this in e-Sun PETg filament, 240C, bed with painter's tape at 60C. Printed at 100% scale, but shrinkage may vary from printer to printer and material to material, so please comment with any other settings that work.

This should be printed flat on its back for best results.

The case thickness is 1.2mm, so a .4mm nozzle works best.

Measured my new Pixel 2 with digital calipers. It took several design iterations before the slots lined up exactly on the camera and fingerprint reader, and several more before the fit was just right.

Ok... this is an odd one that might make some of you uncomfortable... apologies.
But, if you, or a loved one needs this, it can literally be a life-saver, or at the very least, a HUGE pain reliever.

So, a loved one of mine just got stomach surgery. If you've ever heard of, or been thru this type of surgery, you'll know they pump your body cavity full of CO2 to spread things out for the surgery. Afterwards, whatever gas they couldn't get out (sometimes it's a LOT), your body has to absorb and .... expel. Yes, that means burping and farting. But, if your abdomen has just been operated on, you have no way to push. It's too painful. And the gas build-up can become overwhelming. The pain of it building for days can be extreme.
So, at her hospital bed, I said, I can fix this when we get home. And within 2 hrs of being back home at my printer, she finally had relief. And it was amazing and instant. A little vaseline to smooth the insertion, and this becomes an instant relief valve (yes, you insert it in your anus). It worked so well, she slept with it for 2 days. Her stomach was empty anyway... just gas.

I debated publishing this for days.... but seriously, if you're in her boat, or know someone that is, you will find this to be a god-send.
If you or a loved one finds this to be as amazing as we did, please let me know. :o)

You may download and modify this for personal use, but check the license, it is NOT for commercial use. ;o)

description.text: The Taig Micro Lathe is a great tool. One of it's biggest strengths is the ability to modify and improve it. Unfortunately, this seems to have led to certain aspects of the design that appear unfinished. The front and back of the lathe bed is one such area. The lack of any kind of finished end on the lathe bed has always annoyed me. It doesn't affect the functioning of the tool at all, it just seems as if its something that should have been addressed. These caps solve that problem. The cap will fit in either end of the lathe bed and I designed them to be a loose fit, so a dab of super glue will be needed to secure them. These are purely aesthetic and don't alter the functioning of the lathe in any way.

title: OctoPrint/Raspberry pi case for QIDI Tech 1 Printer (creator forge clone)

description.text:
Raspberry PI Case for QIDI Tech 1 (featuring OctoPrint)

Raspberry PI Case for the QIDI Tech 1 printer. If you are using OctoPrint then this will be handy. The case might also fit the creator forge.

Compatibility

  • Fits a Raspberry Pi B+ (and probably a Pi3) with the ports facing up when mounted on the right side of the printer
  • If you are using Octoprint, then this would be fine to use with a webcam, but NOT the built in pi camera port since it won't easily reach.
  • Requires swapping to the slightly longer screws that come with the printer.
  • Snap on Lid!

Other notes

  • Mounts on right side of printer.
  • Board mounts to the LID not the PRINTER
  • Requires SUPER GLUE on the mounting pegs to hold the Raspi.

STL and f3d (Fusion 360) files included.

Setting up OctoPrint with QIDI

See https://octoprint.org/

You will need the standard OctoPrint setup, plus the GPX plugin for OctoPrint to convert gcode to x3g.

The GPX plugin is BUGGY! Have your finger over the 'cancel print' button on the printer, or it will sometimes grind the filament before the extruder heats up. Kind of annoying but works like a dream otherwise.

Under GPX Settings - Choose "Replicator 1 - Dual Extruder" -- this is the correct steps per mm

description.text:
Why not a RetroPie project portable that can be also connected to a TV and played like a regular Raspberry?

I'm not the best to 3D design, but it works for me. But if you want to change anything I'm also sharing the .f3d file for Fusion360.

Used a 4,3" composite screen soldered directly to the PP24 and ground video in PP6.

PP25 and 26 for sound output. A PAM8403 is used for audio amplifier.

Then, a PS3 controller is used inside and soldered directly to USB and tactile buttons

When you want to play on TV, just plug it directly to the HDMI and be happy!

Material List:
Disclaimer: These are not exactly the link where I bought, is just a model. So you might find cheaper

  • 4,3" Composite Screen
    https://goo.gl/qYfAMf
    Some composite screens are made for 12V but works with 5V.

  • XL6009 Step-up voltage converter
    https://goo.gl/x2Qboc

  • Mini Audio Amplifier PAM8403
    https://goo.gl/ZWpwT3 (You migh want to take off the header and connectors to solder directly to the board and save space)

  • A mini power switch like this
    https://goo.gl/ZKmFya

  • PS3 Chinese controller
    https://goo.gl/Mp4Ng2 (Using just the board)

  • Some tactile switches (14, i think)
    https://goo.gl/H8LfvQ

  • Prototype Solder Board
    https://goo.gl/Yfw4eF

  • TP4056 Battery charger with protection
    https://goo.gl/jh6wwe

  • 4x 3,7V 18650 Battery
    https://goo.gl/FveduX

  • Green and red 5mm LED's (soldered in the Battery Charger)

  • Raspberry Pi 3

[EDIT: 06/02/18]

I had some problem with the chinese PS3 controller board. So I replaced it for a Arduino Pro Micro (32u4 chip, the same as Leonardo) as you can see in the last picture.

The code used in the Arduino controll is in the files!

This is the library I used: https://github.com/gamelaster/ArduinoGamepad

Instructable made by the guy who made the Library: http://www.instructables.com/id/Arduino-LeonardoMicroATMega32u4-As-GamepadGame-Con/

title: Safety Keck Clips - 14/20, 19/22, 24/40 Taper Joint Clips

description.text: These Keck clips are made fail-safe by threading wire spines salvaged from common household twist-wraps through one or both of the eyelet pairs and twisting off. Safety pins are also a good choice. Do not use for suspending large flasks or assemblies if the clips will be exposed to temps of 90C or greater. The eyelets only stop things from dropping if the loops become severed when operating within the normal temperature range. At hot temps, the crescent rings may relax and lose grip entirely. After applying clips, always give the two joints a tug to make sure the clip has seated properly above the shoulder on the male joint. Print clips with medium infill and thick surface layer (4-5 layers). The connecting loops on clips printed with solid fill are prone to delamination at the crest during flexing.

Original style kecks available here:
14/20: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:274395
19/22: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:275257
24/40: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:274563

I recommend printing with about 75% infill and 4-5 layer surface. When printed solid, some of the connecting loops are prone to cracking at the apex and eventually splitting. I believe having less than solid infill allows the loops to distribute the flexing forces more evenly rather than concentrating at the crest. I haven't noticed any decrease in strength compared to the solid prints

comments.text: Will 14/20 work for 14/18?
comments.author: Printedindustry

comments.text:
It should be fine. The 14/20 clip demonstrated in picture #3 is clipped over a 14/20 RB-flask with a 14/18 thermometer adapter and it holds just fine.. Like I said to another comment on this page; the first figure refers to the major diameter of the taper and the last figure specifies the overall length of the taper. The taper angle is standardized and identical for all 14/XX STJ. A 14/18 joint will fit into a 14/20 female joint and a 14/20 joint will fit into a 14/18 joint but will stick out by 2 mm.
.
The 14/20 keck clip uploaded here should work on most 14/18 glassware, but the dimensions of the taper (i.e. 14 mm major diameter x 18 mm long) are the only things that have manufacturing standards to them; the external dimensions of the joints such as the overall thickness of the glass have no such standards as far as I know, and therefor this clip may work with some 14/18 glassware but not with some of a different manufacturer.
comments.author: Printedindustry

comments.text: Will you make a 14/23 version?
comments.author: Anti-Quark42

comments.text: A 14/20 clip should also work for 14/23. 23 is just the length of the taper. AFAIK, they are the same taper angle and both are 14 mm at the opening, which is all that matters.

title: Wolf - Red Hot Riding Hood, Tex Avery

description.text:
Wolfie harassed Red, but he always got a mallet to the head. Maybe we need more cartoon violence nowadays.

I took both Red and Wolfie to work. Some of my co-workers reacted like Red was some sort of dangerous snake, they're so gun shy over sexual harassment. So, only Wolfie gets to stay at work. Red and two other wolves reside on the fridge.

I uploaded all the components separately. Group them as you choose.

Black

  • Outline
  • Suit, change to silver at 1.2 mm to get the pants and collar highlights.
  • Mouth, start with black, change to red at 0.4 mm. You could print all of the mouth red, but the black layer makes the back of his mouth darker.

White

  • Eyes, collar, change to black at 1.2 to get the bulging pupils and bow tie.
  • Hands, Fang 1 and Fang 2 (yes they are small, print a couple extra just in case)

Silver (or grey)

  • Shoes, Head, Wrist.

Flesh

  • Ear
  • Jowls, change to black at 1.2 mm to get his nose and moustache, change to white at 1.6 mm to get the highlight on his nose.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm, but Cura didn't pause correctly for the jowls unless I used 0.1 mm. Your choice

Infill:

100

Notes:

Print it out, stick it together with super glue. Make sure the head piece is in the right position. It can slip too low and interfere with the jowls.

Hope you enjoy it!

title: Modular Paint Rack, Vertical Storage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This paint rack uses a minimum of material, prints quickly, and can be expanded with as many ranks as needed. It holds standard model paint sizes for Tamiya, Mr. Hobby, Model Master, and possibly others. (The internal diameter of the holder is 36.5 mm)

A taller pillar installed between the racks will fit the larger Model Master bottles.

The build method is simple: Assemble the pieces and flood the seams with thin CA glue. When the assembly is sturdy, secure to a backing board with No. 0 (4 x 1/2) wood screws.

One rank consists of:

Paint_M-Rack_Bottom.stl x 1
Paint_M-Rack_Top.stl x 1
Paint Right Side.stl x 1
Paint Left Side.stl x 1
Paint Riser.stl x 4

… and either

Pillar A (normal).stl x 2
or
Pillar B (tall).stl x 2

title: Slim Phast 4" Shark Fin - Short & Medium Versions

description.text:
These are top plates with shark fins for the RC Crazed 4" Slim Phast drone. If you use this in addition to your original top plate, it should be pretty tough. A similar shark fin that is available for purchase has a shark fin that is about 44mm tall. Unfortunately, I've seen it break a couple of times. The "short" one here is about 20mm tall. The "medium" one is about 30mm tall. They should be tall enough to give the quad a chance to be able to flip over using turtle mode when it lands upside down. These do not have an EXACT fit to the top plate, but they are real close.

The orange fin in the pics is an original from rccrazed.com. In the pics, the black one is PLA and the orange is TPU. PLA would be really stiff. On the short one, the fin is short enough that the PLA could most likely withstand crashes, but I think TPU would be the better filament to use.

The center screw hole spacing is 30mm side-to-side and 40mm front-to-back.

Here's a link to the RC Crazed Slim Fast 4" frame: http://www.rccrazed.com/frames-rc-crazed-rc-crazed-slim-phast-p-610.html

title: Anycubic I3 Mega Silent Extruder Lever

description.text:
This lever stops the annoying loud "click" noise coming from the extruder unit.
(Just fit a short 4mm dia. PTFE teflon tube in the hole,
printing position should be same as the image shown above.)

Have you ever wondered where the clicking noise is coming from?
There's so many false claim about what makes the "click" noise, such as
...Extruder motor does not have enough torque.
...Extruder gear is slipping, etc.

But none of the above are the real reasons.
Here is the real cause:
The original metal extruder lever wobbles slightly even if the screw is tight
and it hits against the metal mounting bracket with high speed which causes the loud "click".
It occurs more often during the filament retraction.

title: Nerf crush flywheel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Because of the apparent lack of free modified flywheel models on the interwebs I decided to make some! I based this design off of stock flywheels, with a few measurements from some informative Youtube videos (thanks Bobo!) and this is the result. My printer's finished model is a bit rough, and the tinkercad software has some low res shape settings for the concave perimiter, but with a flywheel gap of roughly 10 mm, it should result in more traction without ripping up darts, we'll see. Will likely require a little finish work, and your results may vary. I've found that they fit the canted Rapidstrike / Stryfe flywheel cage beautifully, found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2479577
I will possibly get some pictures of fitment into said cage and a firing video up soon. These will probably pair well with upgraded motors, like torque-laden fangs.
I plan on making some vented variants later, but in the mean time let me know what you think, if you see any room for improvement, and don't be afraid to let me know about your projects and post pictures.

1/15/2018 I added a new model of a smoother design, I found a better shape profile in tinkercad to use. Also added vents on the top of the flywheel. The new design should be almost identical to the first design, just more consistent and smoother surface in the groove.

2/9/2018 I did a little testing of my own and these definitely need to be used in a 42.5mm or narrower cage, There are feeding issues on stock cages. I will attempt to model a stock wheel with a larger outer diameter, and a bigger diameter convex wheel to get more grip in stock cages if possible. Stay tuned.

2/13/2018 I added a plain upsized flywheel to the list, it should be as close to stock as possible, just up 2.5mm bigger from stock diameter. should just barely fit, and give more crush in stock cages, just no convex surface. Hopefully it will be good for any blaster that doesn't have a bunch of upgrades, like just voltage mods with stock motors.

description.text:
I installed a e3dv6 clone with Volcano on my CR-10, and while things work, I had maybe 3 if not 4 threads left to adjust my bed (and at some point (2-1) the bed starts flapping around. So while I was taught and things were good, I didn't like being at the edge. The stock mount is 12mm tall, mine is 10mm, also 10mm wide (9.9mm) (which is almost like the stock setup (this has to be taken into consideration on how the Z rod works, make sure it's not tweaked out of level etc.

But this fits well, replacing the stock mounts and gives you a ton of adjustability. I've got about double the threads now.

NOTE: I don't know if you need an adjustable Z end stop for this, but I'm using one.

I'm much happier knowing I've got some threads to work with and my bed is nice and taught.

Update v2:

Just recessed the top m3 screws, I didn't get them recessed properly, so now I've got the full saved space!

Requires: M3x12, the stock m3x16 won't work..

description.text:
DAwhoopy80

Brushless 11xx indoor racer

Hi guys,

Winter is here and it's time to fly indoors.

I always wanted a Tinywhoop. All these indoor videos in YT made me to create my own one.

One of the things that I really wanted to try are the influence of ducts on thrust as many mention it to add some extra lift performance which I can say definitely that it improves.

When designing a micro quadcopter you have to keep it light as possible and with my setup I keep it 48gr which is not that bad.

This frame is designed for 16*16mm pattern electronics

I included 2" and 2.5" props options

Print 100mtm frame with 65mm ducts to match

Print 80mtm frame with 2 inch ducts to match

I included Micro swift cam mount in case you need!

My setup based on 16*16mm electronics and 2S batteries

  • Super_S F4 2S Flight Controller and 4in1 6A esc's link.

  • 1102 10000kv Brushless motor link

  • Frsky XM+ receiver link

  • Micro swift FPV cam v2 + 200Mw Vtx link

  • 2 Inch 4 blade props link

  • To control my racing quadcopters I'm using Taranis X9D link

  • You can benfit from the new budget Taranis X7 Transmitter link

To print my quadcopters I use one of these printers:

Creality CR-10.

Tevo Tornado.

Nice filaments

ABS 1kg.

Another brand I use: ABS 1kg.

Want the frame from carbon? Please contact me

100%

I love to print my quadcopters from ABS, Petg, PC, Nylon.
ABS is quite good for testing if printed in the correct speed and temp.

Using the linked Filaments I print the ABS at 45mm speed and 235c

Goodluck (:

remixed_from.title: Wall Mount - VESA D (100) - For monitor or small TV

title: VESA Mount Wall Bracket - 20 Degree Angle

description.text:
I was going to mount a monitor up high in my workshop, where a completely straight mount would mean a weird viewing angle, as well as showing a reflection of the roof lights.

As such I changed the original wall mount to have a 20 degree wedge underneath it, so that the monitor would then sit with a 20 degree downslope (or upslope if you used it up side down, I guess). I changed the mounting holes so that they remain square to the wall.

Given the increased thickness of the wall mount, I also uprated the mounting holes to use stronger screws - the ones I had on hand, and designed for, are 14g (~6mm) x 75mm hex head timber screws like these (https://www.bunnings.com.au/zenith-14g-x-75mm-galvanised-hex-head-type-17-timber-screws-5-pack_p2420369)

The tall screw hole is 43mm deep (hence the need for a 75mm screw), the shorter one is 22mm deep and a 50mm screw would be a less overkill/more appropriate choice.

EDIT make sure you mirror one of the two mounts you print, so you have a left hand and right hand side to the wedge.

title: Single Perimeter Rocket - Designed for Vase Mode
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Loosely modeled after the Nazi Germany era V-2 rocket. Baked from scratch to be printed in vase mode - and only vase mode. See more info below, as well as a step-by-step guide on how to do it!

Printer:

ProDesk3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Rockets

You all have seen @mechg 's awesome single-perimeter rocket. I had good results printing his model when printing with a smaller (0.1mm) layer, but I had issues when scaling the part or trying to print above 0.2mm layer height.

What I Did

mechg commented on his thing page and said:

If I had it to do over again, instead of making a longitudinal outline and rotating it to make the solid body, I would probably make a series of cross-section circles and use the loft function in FreeCad, as that would make for a smoother body[...]

Well, I took the advice. I created a new model based off the Nazi Germany era V-2 rocket, which I believe was also mechg's inspiration. I created an object in Fusion 360 with its loft function going between five cross-sections. This results in a part that has a single, continuous horizontal perimeter at any point!

How I Printed

I printed this with a 0.63mm layer height on a 0.8mm nozzle. Printed in single perimeter (vase) mode with a 0.96mm layer width. Material is Inland Natural PETG.

Note that the twisty rocket in the pictures was done in Simplify3D, the other one in Slic3r PE. The S3D one didn't mess up because of the slicer; it messed up because I sped it up too much (plus I like it that way).

How You Can Print

Print this in vase/spiral/single-perimeter mode with 0 top and 0 bottom layers. No raft needed with some hairspray and a calibrated printer. Print just enough of a skirt to get the nozzle flowing.

Here's how I made this object in Fusion 360! I made the outline of the base using lines and circles. I created an offset plane to add the next outline. Then I traced the outline of the rocket at the top of the fins. Note that the outer circles are missing to taper in the flare on the sides. Used the Loft function to connect the first two sketches. Created another offset plane for the next part; here you can see how it is positioned in the final view. Next one's a circle for the base of the cylinder-like portion. Then, in a perpendicular plane, I attached the center of sketches #2 and #3 in order to create a center line for the loft. An orthographic view of the centerline. Used the loft function to connect sketches #2 and #3 with the centerline being sketch #4. Next, another plane. Sketch a circle. Final plane... ~~Final destination~~ Tiny circle at the end. Final use of the loft function Use the Export function to get an STL for 3D printing. That's it! Thanks for reading (:

author: mbuc91

title: Simple Glass Corner Bed Clamp - Tevo Tornado

description.text:
I didn't care for the paper-clip look. Also didn't find many options for Tornado so I designed these. They work with the 3mm glass bed I bought on eBay, I think it's a pretty standard thickness. The slot is biased up slightly for clearance of the hotend/fan assembly. Kept the thickness down below for rigidity. Made them very snug to avoid having to add screws, so they may require a few gentle taps with a small mallet or just some elbow grease to seat fully. You have to get them on all the way as the clearance between the back corner clamps and side posts is tight!

...I'm new to this and this is my first little design and share, so... hope you like them!

comments.text: No problem with these corners deforming so far, but I'm curious to see if that does happen with more use. They have seen maybe 10-12 hours of use with the bed set at 80°C. But the Tornado's bed does seem to be quite a bit cooler at its perimeter (everywhere outside the actual heating pad) so maybe that helps. I do have some other stuff to try like Polycarbonate and Delrin if I run into issues. I got this thing for Xmas (thank you, awesome wife!) and so far have not printed with anything but the PLA while I learn to get it all tuned in before going on to the other materials.

I haven't printed this yet. But it is my housing for a RADDS board with Arduino Due and LDC screen.

Feel free to let me know of any errors or issues you see or find. Once I've printed one, I'll put up pics. Doubtless it needs tweaking. I'm just sticking it here in case my cloud server decides to break again...

The pegs are to locate the screen cover. They DO need tweaking, the holes are 3mm and so are the pegs. You could use screws I guess. I dunno, I'm still tinkering! I haven't made buttons or knobs yet, and I haven't made a hole for the stepper cables either, because it's a work in progress!!

EDIT 12/01/18

Added more vents (more to make it easier to remove from the build plate than for ventilation) and added a hole for stepper cables. Also tweaked the rails a little for clearance on the bottom of the Due board. Embossed the back of it to just for fun.

EDIT 30/01/18

Did a very quick rough print of this to make sure it fits. Need to tweak a couple of things slightly, but all in all it fits, works, and looks great!

Let me Know if you have any suggestions.

Simple construction blocks that connect using zip-ties.
Updated the files.   Now with Parameters.  
The .scad files will let you define your own custome zip plates.

This is a construction set that allows you to make a platform for a robot, circuit board holder, etc.  You use 4" zip-ties to connect them. (although you can change parameters to use other sizes) My plan is to create many different size plates, spacers, stand-offs, wire management, and hopefully more.  At is basic you use two zip-ties, on the first zip-tie is used to connect all the pieces in a straight line, the second zip-tie only he head is needed and is used to snug all the pieces together.  
I guess the question that everyone will have is; why?  Well, I donâ€™t have a bunch of screws and nuts lying around.  Other constructions sets donâ€™t have all the parts that I will want.  Hopefully I will have a good set of items and maybe other people will also have ideas.  I will be working on the .scad files to make them with parameters.  
I have create a .scad file that will let you have full control of the Zip-Plate.  It allows features at each of the spacing locations.  Features include: Solid, Big hole (useful to create contiguous holes in a board), zip tie hole, zip tie hold rotated 90 degrees, a round hole the size of the zip tie width, or a custom size hole.  You will have to play with it a bit, but all you have to do is change the values in the big matrix.  It can support a board at 205mm by 205mm if your spacing is set to 5mm.

comments.text: I agree - promising. I was searching Thingiverse for an OpenSCAD zip tie to replace some screws in existing stuff. This is a good start at replacing lots more screws.

Another case version of the DPS5005 module.

As the power supply I used for this is large and loud (48V/5A Meanwell with fans) it has to go under my desk. I wanted to be able to switch that on/off through the "control panel" on the desk. For this the mains power is going to the switch in the desk unit first, then to the Meanwell PSU.
The solution includes a 5cm fan with temperature control, powered by a HiLink power brick for mains to 12V.

Includes rubber feet to be printed in flex material like Ninjaflex.

The screw holes of the body are intended for 4mm melt-in nuts with 3mm thread, but you can use short 4mm screws as well (though the thread will wear out open/closing the case more often). Use 3mm screws and regular nuts for the rubber feet.
The thread holes in the back wall are intended to be screwed in directly with 3mm screws.
Use standard banana plug sockets for front and back.
The power sockets/plugs are "Bachmann 917.170 Kaltgerätestecker" (plug = input) and "Bachmann 917.171 Kaltgeräteeinbaudose".
The lighted power switch is a "Bachmann 924.099 Wippenschalter".

UPDATE 19 Jan 2018:
I have fixed the backside where both mains connections were plugs. Now one is a plug and one is a socket. New back wall STL is in the set.

Post a picture in "Makes" if you build it!

title: Delta Carriage for 2020 Aluminum V-Slot® 20x20 Linear Rail

description.text:
This is a remix of Hayden Huntley's 2020 Carriages for Zero-Backlash Magnetic Arms https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2183347. I wanted a carriage to be mounted on the Openbuilds V-Slot Gantry 20mm plate.

Here is a list of materials I used:

Parts for one carriage:
3 pieces of Xtreme Solid V Wheel™ Kit, http://openbuildspartstore.com/xtreme-solid-v-wheel-kit/
2 pieces of M5 x 6mm spacers, http://openbuildspartstore.com/aluminum-spacers
1 of the M5 x 6mm eccentric spacers, http://openbuildspartstore.com/eccentric-spacer/
1 of the V-Slot Gantry Plate 20mm, http://openbuildspartstore.com/v-slot-gantry-plate-20mm/
3 M5 x 25mm button head bolts for three axles.
2 M5 x 16mm button head bolts to secure the carriage to the gantry plate.
7 M5 flat washers.
5 M5 nylon lock nuts for three axles and two for securing the carriage to the gantry plate .
2 3/8" ball studs from Hayden Huntley http://www.MagBallArms.com.
4 M3 nylock nuts, 2 to secure the ball studs, one for securing the G2 belt to the vertical post and one to secure the upper G2 belt.
4 M3 flat whashers, two for the M3 x 40mm bolts, one to go under the M3 nylon lock that secures the G2 belt to the vertical post, one to go under the M3 nylon lock nut that secures the upper G2 belt.
2 M3 x 40mm hex bolt for the tightener.
1 M3 x 12mm hex bolt for securing the upper G2 belt.
1 M3 x 20mm flat head for the vertical post G2 belt attachment.
1 M3 16mm hex or button head bolt for End stop adjusting (optional).
5 M3 nuts, 2 for the G2 belt tightener, 1 to secure the vertical post to the carriage, one to be inserted in the slot near the top of the carriage for the end stop adjusting bolt and one to lock down the end stop adjusting bolt (see the pictures).

description.text:
Hook and Hanger System

Update 16Jan2018 - Added a two piece hook design that doesn't require support structures when printing.

This is a simple but flexible system of hooks and rod hangers for the kitchen or workshop.
It's based on a 1 inch (or 25mm) wooden dowel rod which you can purchased from the hardware store. Or you can use something else such as a 3/4" PVC pipe.
If you print the parts from something like Hatchbox® wood filled PLA filament, you can stain everything to match your woodwork.

There are four different styles of hangers: Small, large, with and without a slotted opening. The version with the slotted opening allows you to easily add or remove hooks after installing.

There are also four different styles of hooks: Large, small, parallel and perpendicular to the dowel rod. The hooks are captured on the dowel rod so they can’t fall off but you can still slide them around as needed. You can easily design your own hooks. If you do, please share them here!
Of course, you can go without the hooks and use the parts to make things such as towel racks.

PRINTING INSTRUCTIONS:

The rod hangers can be printed without support. The STL files are oriented in the proper direction for this.

Some of the hooks will require that you add support. (Also see the two piece version that doesn't require support.) For strength, the large side of the hook should be parallel to the build plate. The STL files have been oriented this way.
Layer thickness can be whatever you like. I used 0.2mm in my parts.
The percentage of infill you use depends on the strength you need. I used 30%.

print_settings.Notes:: No rafts or supports required, recomend PETG for this print to reduce heat damage from accidental soldering iron touches.

title: Budget solid Raspberry Pi laptop with 7 inch screen

description.text:
Features

  • Visible IOs: RJ-45, hdmi, 3.5mm, usb 2.0 * 6
  • Display remaining battery power (if the powerbank circuit support that)
  • Charge while running (if the powerbank circuit support that)
  • Remove and install sd card on the Raspberry Pi is super easy
  • Minimum screws.

Tips

  • The powerbank circuit looks powerful, but the lcd draws a lot of currency, so the Pi always show the "lack of power" mark on the screen.
  • The usb ports on Pi are replaced with two AF90 usb female ports. The two free ones are connected to the keyboard dongle and the usb hub circuit.
  • I print the coverD with transparent PLA, looks great.
  • The powerbank circuit uses a lockless button (click to power on, push down for 4 secs to power off), but I bought a slide switch, so, I have to manually simulate the lockless behavior on a slide switch.
  • The 18650 cells physically support the keyboard. But it is a little crowded. If you use 14500 cells instead, you'd better print several holders to support the keyboard.

Future plans

I am satisfied with what I made, but there is still some improvments I can make.

  • A thicker coverD, no need to remove the usb ports on the Pi, 18650 cells don't touch the keyboard, no internal usb hub, larger free space (for larger battery capacity & currency or some kind of air cooling method).
  • Many defective details.

description.text:
This is an alternate top for the dice tray in 7SoulFox's "Dice Box/Tray/Thing". I wanted something that wasn't a simple cut-through design, or solid plate, so I did a quick plate to use instead. This is a dual-material print (although I suppose technically it could be up to seven material if you had an appropriate printer). I printed the panel in wood filament, and the rest in black PLA. You could also print it single material by loading all the parts into your slicer and not setting an alternate extruder to use for the different parts.

I printed at .15mm layers, 20% infill, no supports or anything. The dice have minimal overhangs by design, so they should print on pretty much any printer without supports. I also used an "octagram spiral" for the top/bottom layer fill pattern, as it generally looks better when stained as wood filament.

I haven't done prep sanding or stained my box yet, so I don't have a good "finished" photo, just the rough one, so I uploaded a rendering.

Note, if you have a single material printer, its possible you could print all of these separately and assemble them with glue. It might take some filing to get it all to fit, but the openings for all of the dice, I think, could probably take the dice after printing. Maybe print them 99% or something for some clearance and use some CA glue.

The dice models are from here: https://grabcad.com/library/dice--4

I have this tagged as a remix... technically its not, its a from-scratch remake of the panel in Fusion360, but it seems to pretty closely match the original.

comments.text: Hi! I've been using this for a couple of days and its worked perfectly, but it seems to have lead to the erosion of my filament switch and now I have squeaky noises during retraction. Is there any way this can be fixed??
comments.author: smartyapple

comments.text:
Hi. Filament Switch? I dont have one of those. But could imagine if its made of a similar/same plastic that your are running through the machine, then it may squeak. I made mine from PETG so it more durable and "slippery".
Note that the squeaking might be the actual YELLOW EXTRUDE block because the guide moves the filament feed sideways a little, away from the Z screw but this makes it ride the original extrude block a bit.
I'd also guess the squeak will disappear in time, I had a few on the CR10 ... but aside from the fan noise, have gone.

description.text:
Since I have had my printer I have made and installed many upgrades designed by others as well as my self. I noticed my Xaxis was off when I installed my X stop switch. At this point, I put a tac in it.

6 Months Later.....

I was printing larger footprint prints and eyeballing it was just not cutting it anymore. So here is my simple fix.

  1. Use new Tape
  2. find the CENTROID
  3. print The CENTROID
  4. Mesure offset
  5. Adjust slicer.
  6. Have a beer for a job well done.

description.text:
Here is a blade possible for my modular lightsabers. You can adjust the blade size as you want. With the LED lamps I use, there is not much light into the blade. But it's still cool having a blade, and a really cheap one !

I wanted to get a lightsaber, really cheap for cosplays or decoration. I wanted something, easy to make, with no electronic circuit which has to be made each time you construct a saber.

I use a LED keyring torch as a lamp which is at the back of the saber. The light is not very powerful of course, but it could be enough if you are using it in dark places. Moreover, you can add a little piece of plastic to change the color oh the saber (like a Kyber crystal !)

The LED i'm using : Infapower F026 5-LED Keyring Torch

You can find what you need to build the lightsaber here : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2751428

I find it perfect for kids who want to get a customisable saber, or as a decoration for your house.

Bed complet pour Anet A8

Full-box insert for Gaia Project!

The "Most Things" tray holds the tech tiles that have the green marker on the back for randomization, round boosters, round bonuses, advanced tech tiles, game-end bonuses, and all the cards. The five inlay prints are meant to be put into the bottom of this tray so that the tiles are closer to the top of it.

The Tech Tile tray holds the nine tech tiles when you double up on one stack.

The Federation Token and Gaia Planet tray fits into the Tech Tile tray.

You should print eight of the Player Trays. It is easiest if you print them with different colors, otherwise it will be difficult to figure out which color is in each. I recommend putting the faction specific pieces (Taklon Brainstone, Ivit Space Stations, Gleen Federation Token) in with that faction's pieces. The eighth player tray (green in my pictures) will hold power discs and QICs.

Attribution
Based on the fantastic foam core plans by Eleates, with some inspiration from the remix by schmu75.

Player box is a customized version of Arvin's Customizable Round Box with Lid.

remixed_from.author: SpannerHands
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Metal Plus Mounted Spool Holder

remixed_from.author: SpannerHands
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Metal Plus E3D v6 & Titan + Blower Fan MOD + Volcano

description.text:
This is my Multi Material Upgrade (MMU) for the Printrbot Metal Plus inspired by the Prusa MMU.

This collection of models has parts that I have remixed from:

Josef Prusa (I used his MMU for a base to make mine) https://www.prusaprinters.org/

SpannerHands (I used his MP spool holder to design the extruder mount) (https://www.thingiverse.com/SpannerHands/about)

Walter (I used his printable housing for printrbot extruder gears) (https://www.thingiverse.com/walter/about)

Please check them all out.

PLEASE NOTE:

This modification does limit the Z axis to 220mm from the standard 254mm, this wasn't a problem for me as I never used the full limit.

This modification has been made to fit MY metal plus which is already modified with the SpannerHand's mods, this involved cutting the X cart which also moved the Z sensor and using a blower fan for part cooling. If you do this mod you can either also use his modifications and you'll be good to go. If you do not want to do the SpannerHand's mods, this will work with an uncut X cart and you should still be able to use the Z sensor as normal, HOWEVER the part cooling fan may not line up. This will be the same for an E3D v6 and UBIS hot end mount, when I make them.

Update - 07/02/2018:

This is the wiki page I used for the wiring guide, http://reprap.org/wiki/Adding_more_extruders

Update - 28/01/2018:

I have made some mounts for both an E3D v6 and a UBIS 13S hot end, these haven't been tested other than a quick test fit but them seem good. I am not sure how well these hot ends will work with the MMU so use at your own risk. I have also remixed part of SpannerHands Printrbot metal plus mod, the lower parts of fan duct "should" fit without any modification and allow you to use either the E3D v6 or UBIS hot end with a blower fan and the lower ducts included here, the parts are named to show which is needed for which hot end.

Hardware:

This is made to fit my Printrbot Metal Plus with the single extruder, it mounts to the metal cart of the X axis with 3 M3 bolts which screw into M3 brass inserts, that have been inserted into the printed part with a soldering iron (See picture). It is as it stands for the DisTech Prometheus V2 Hot End, a E3D V6 & Printrbot UBIS mount coming soon.

I have remixed the Prusa filament guide to use M6 brass inserts (These need cutting shorter, see picture above) and M6 pneumatic fittings. My filament guide does not have tubes in as I drilled out the holes a little but this is up to you.

Included with the filament guide and Hot End camp STL parts you can use the optional dual colour logo's or use the NO_LOGO versions.

I am using the Printrbot gear head extruder gear set. These do not come with the small bearings needed so these had to be ordered from Aliexpress.

The extruders themselves are largely unmodified apart from making holes bigger for brass inserts, they were made as a mirrored pair and mount on the extruder mount with M3 bolts into M3 inserts. The mount uses Spannerhands idea of attaching to the metal frame of the plus, I have added cable tie holes to keep them in place.

Lastly as it is important that one filament is clear of the filament guide before another is inserted I decided to use clear PTFE tube, to help spot if something isn't going well and cut the power before bad things happen. I also think they look cool.

Electronics:

I'm using an Arduino Mega & RAMPS 1.4 board for my main controller, this of course only allows 2 extruders, so I am also using Printrbot's Extrudrboard for the extra 2 extruders. This is connected to the AUX-2 pins on the RAMPS and the firmware configured to use those pins.

Parts list:

  • Prometheus V2 Hot End - https://www.distechautomation.com/products/prometheus-v2

  • Brass inserts M3 & M6 - https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/M3-M4-M5-M6-Threaded-Solid-Brass-Press-in-Barbed-Inserts-for-plastic/262993790868?var=562002386626&hash=item3d3ba6c794:m:mOHTFRbrYIVeJt2c76sT51w

  • M6 pneumatic fittings - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10Pcs-PC4-M6-Pneumatic-Straight-Fitting-Connector-for-4mm-OD-Tubing-M6-6mm-Reprap-For-3D/32668216080.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.3a8KMo

  • Extruder gear set - https://printrbot.com/shop/gear-head-extruder-gear-set/

  • Gear set bearings - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10pcs-Lot-MR85ZZ-Double-shielded-Miniature-Ball-Bearings-5x8x2-5mm-for-3D-Printer-Model-Making-Deep/32812874077.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.3a8KMo

  • Clear PTFE - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/3D-printers-1M-2-4mm-Clear-PFA-PTFE-Tube-Teflon-PiPe-J-head-hotend-RepRap-Rostock/32611337704.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.3a8KMo

  • Printrbot Extrudrboard - Currently Unavailable

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

30%

Brass inserts

So as I said above this set up uses brass inserts embedded into the plastic parts. I insert them with an old 30W soldering iron, just heat it up and place it on one side of the insert while holding it against the plastic part and it melts right in.

The hot end mount needs 5 M3 inserts, 3 are placed in the back of the mount to screw it to the Metal Plus X axis cart and 2 more inserts are need on the front for the hot end clamp to screw into.

The extruder(s) need 1 M3 and 1 M6 insert, these are for the PTFE connector and for screwing the extruders to their mount.

The filament guide needs 4 M6 inserts which if you use the ones linked about need cutting down (see picture)

description.text:
Top and bottom case has been updated. Replaced standoff "nubs" with mounting holes. Mounting holes updated to 2.6mm diameter (works with M2.5 x 5mm screws). Holder updated to better house slide switch.

Raspberry Pi Retro Game Console
This project takes the original concept of the PiGRRL and makes it more powerful, using a Raspberry Pi 2 (or Model B+). It's about the same size but features more buttons (D-Pad, A, B, X, Y, L, R, pause, and start.) and four extra buttons on the PiTFT. It's sporting a small audio amplifier and speaker, so you can enjoy the crispy sounds of 8-bit goodness.

Easier to build!
With this update, we really wanted to make it easier to build. We've dramatically cut the build time in half by making a custom gamepad PCB. Just solder the buttons and an IDC box header to the gamepad PCB - No more tedious button wiring!

Project Expectations
This project is geared towards beginners but is still a big project to take on. This guide will walk you through all the necessary steps to wire, assemble and build your very first Raspberry Pi game console. It does require a good amount of soldering, wire tinning and good old' elbow grease, but don't be discouraged! If you're dedicated to taking on this project, it'll only take a weekend to make.

description.text:
Use this Thing, and a door, to hang a garment bag, dry cleaning, a long dress, etc.

Printed in PETG, this hanger is quite strong. I had my full body weight on it, and I was more concerned that the door hinges would fail before this hanger failed!

The thickness of the part that wraps around the top of the door is 2mm, and this is thin enough to allow most interior doors to be fully closed without interfering with the door jam.

I have provided a version with the decorative star, and a version without the decorative star.

The decorative medallion comes in two versions: one that has a blank name plate, and one that has no name plate.

I printed one of these for each bridesmaid of a bridal party. I customized each with the name of a bridesmaid.

Use PETG for the main body, and use whatever filament is convenient for the other parts. PETG has the property of being strong and flexible.

I printed at 0.2mm layer height, 50% infill. Use supports to print the main body, and to print the medallion.

I printed the main body in Atomic Filament Clear. I printed the other parts in PLA, and used gold spray paint to finish the star and medallion.

1. Use super glue to attach the star.
  2. Wad up a couple of layers of masking tape and place the wad inside the hole on the back side of the medallion.
  3. Insert the mounting plug into the hole on the back of the medallion. If the rim of the plug will not clear the rim of the opening on the back of the medallion (allowing partial insertion), then reduce the size of the mini wad of tape.
  4. Put super glue on the widest diameter of the plug, and while holding the rim of the medallion, press the plug into place in the opening on the main body. Press on the center of the face of the medallion to make sure that the plug fully inserted.
  5. Wait for the glue on the plug / main body to cure.
  6. Pull off the medallion and discard the mini wad of tape.
  7. Use super glue to attach the medallion to the plug.

Upper track for garage door pieces

I finished up with the Tronxy X3 control box removal and started to work on the X3S version. NOTE: This is for the kit version of the X3S. It may work on the pre-built version too. The pre-built version uses the exact same components in the control box so it should work. I have a couple of the X3S pre-built printers and the main difference is the 20x40 frame rather than the 20x20 frame on the kit printer. There are a few other differences but those should not affect this conversion.

Start with the legs and get the frame up off of the table so that the components can be mounted. Attach the legs with 4mmx10mm screws and "boat" nuts. Start with the ones on the bottom of the legs and then install the side screws. You will need to slide the nuts in from the side.

The PC boards and enclosure covers attach with RC servo screws (#2 or 2mm self tapping screws).

The reset switch extension is made with a piece of filament that the ends have been flattened using a soldering iron. To straighten the filament you can place it on the heat bed while printing and the filament should relax and go back to the straight way it was extruded. If it doesn't, heat the filament with a heat gun and as soon as you see it start to go limp, lay it down on your table top or cool heat bed and roll it. It will become arrow straight.

Both a 20A stock power supply mount and the 30A mount is included. The 30A is a good upgrade for the X3S.

Another good upgrade is the MatterHackers magnetic build plate. Super easy to remove those big prints!

Enjoy the added convenience of having the printer as one piece to move and less table top area taken up.

I have designed many cases in the past 6 months for the Raspberry Pi and have only uploaded on of them to Thingiverse. But I have been working on a new case for a week now. It is not like any other case I can find on Thingiverse and the internet and is totally unique.
I present to you The Pi. The first case in the shape of the Raspberry Pi logo. You have access to all the ports including the GPIO. More info will be posted on the design process and tips for printing on http://Gromfrog.com soon.

I now have a Raspberry Pi and have designed this around all of the dimensions of my Pi. But alot of people get very slight adjustments in sizes and some cases do not fit. But this should as there is a little space for slightly smaller and larger Pi's. Now for the instructions.
I have included the full bottom of the case so that people who have printers with a large build area can print the full base. But as most people on Thingiverse have Makerbot's and other home printers I have split up the base so you can print it out in 4 parts and stick them together.
You will need to print the bottoms 1,2,3,4 once and assemble this should be easy as all you need to do is place parts in arrangement until the resemble the logo, then just add some glue to each of the parts to each other and let them dry. I recommend printing all these parts with around a 10-40% infill. These parts will not require support material.
The top half of the case is small enough to be printed in one piece on the Makerbot Replicator. This part will require support material to support the structure during printing. I also recommend printing this part with around a 10-40% infill. Once completed remove all support material from the part including the cylinders that go in to the part to help hold the part to the others.
Now it is time to fit your Pi in. Place your Pi on your completed base with the SD Card slot face out the back towards the leaf/things on the case. This may be a tight fir but it should fit someway or another. Now plug in all of your devices such as your TV, Mouse/Keyboard and even GPIO Devices.
Now that you have your Pi in the base and all of your cables attached you can now place the top of the case on. You may need to use abrasive paper to make the fit better but the top should slide over the poles on top of the base and line up with all four corners. Once you have done this you are ready to use your new unique case.
You may also want to paint the case in the colours of the original logo. I will be uploading more different/quirky cases over the next couple of months.
[Update: 28/07/12 @ 18:56 GMT] I have tried uploading this model to Shapeways but the cheapest cost they can print at is Â£938.46 and the most expensive well over Â£10,000 which is a lot so I will not be selling this model on Shapeways due to the cost.

Just something I've been playing around with trying to learn OpenSCAD.

It's pretty big model, but you can scale it down to whatever size lure you want. There's 2 holes through the model to run a piece of wire down to a treble hook in the back.

With the SCAD file, the pectoral fins are adjustable for attack angle degrees, sweep back, width, length & height. The size hole for the wire to the hook is adjustable too.

Print it with a brim and supports for the pectoral fins if the attack angle is excessive. Use a cooling fan on full speed and print on tape with a cool bed for best results.

description.text:
The Doorman is a project to greet your visitors!

When motion is present, the eyes will open to look around.

What you'll need to build this:

1x Arduino
5 x Servo
5 x capacitor 3300 µf
1 x batterypack ( 4AA )
1 x PIR sensor
2 x 3mm Universal Joint
I used Pattex glue to put it all together and acrylic paste to fill up anything that needed be filled up.

Not the easiest project but a lot of fun!

Note: not everything might fit together perfect and some tweaking will be needed.

The eye mechanism was found here ( forgot the eyelids, but they're in here ): http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Animatronic-Eye-Mechanism-on-the-Cheap/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email

I think I have a problem. Got this game for Christmas a few weeks ago and designed and printed most of this before I even tried playing the game. Card trays are pretty tall, but might make for room for add-ons (don't know what add-ons are out there, or if I'll ever get any).

Printed on my Prusa I3 mk2s fine. Only issue was the large card trays, they are exactly the full printable width of the bed (250mm), so I had to turn off any brim or skirts. Everything else worked fine with default Slic3r PE set to normal 0.2.

My initial design for the token tray had the cutouts a bit too small to easily get tokens out so I made them larger, I also made it a bit taller as I had miscalculated the amount of health tokens (they all fit but just barely). I'm not going to print again though just for those issues, if you print it and its still wonky let me know and I'll update.

I wanted to design it so you could use the trays in-game, and I think I did. I use the separators to keep track of discards and cards removed from game.

Print one of everything except the large card trays (x2) and separators (as desired)

Update: After a few playthroughs, I found it annoying to get the tickets, eldritch tokens and gates out. So I made some simple lifters, they should make it a bit easier.

I also made a basic lid to keep pieces from falling out if the box gets turned over.

Update 2: I really like designing for a quick setup wherever possible. Ideally you should be able to just lift out the trays and start playing. So I trimmed a few mm off the token/card tray , and added a lid frame. Print the lid and the frame, then, if you want to, glue the flat part of the lid to the flat part of the frame (you don't have to glue it, it fits fine, just makes for one less piece of clutter when playing. The frame allows for the character, elder one, reference and mystery cards. It works well for storage, but also does a nice job of keeping them neat during play. When fitted on top of the token tray, the total height of all storage components should be 54mm, which allows a good fit for the game board and manuals, and keeps all components in their spots.

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Mount for CR-10

description.text:
First remix - be gentle with the comments! :-)

This is a combination of three Things to allow mounting of a Raspberry Pi Camera onto the frame of a CR-10. I wanted a straight-on view and most of the arms attach to the bed so I put together pieces from multiple Things to get what I wanted.

The main arms are part of yyh110's Modular Mounting System (thing 2194278). I also used an Axis Change connector from the system to attach the camera enclosure.

The camera enclosure is from alexspeller's Adjustable Raspberry Pi & Camera mounting solution for Prusa i3 (thing 192364)

Lastly I attached it to the frame of my printer (using the extra T-Bolts that came with it) using zaperox's Wanhao i3 Modular Mounting System Bracket (thing 2260802).

I opted to use metal M5 screws (25s) and nuts to assemble it rather than the printed screws/nuts of the Modular Mounting Kit.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

I was recently browsing Thingiverse for a fun project when I stumbled on the Rubberband Rocket by tecdroid. I was inspired by it and spent a day or so rebuilding this from the ground up.
The original idea belongs to tecdroid and so even though I never downloaded or used his model I thought it was appropriate to post this as a remix.
I have also uploaded the art if you want to print your own stickers for the model.
Cheers, and thank you tecdroid.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FVzDtWfUvm4

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Mini

Infill:

solid

Notes:

I recommend printing this with a dense infill, there can be significant stress put on the parts depending on your rubber bands.
PLEASE NOTE: I also highly recommend printing the locking pins and threaded handle horizontally. This will ensure extra strength in those parts. DO NOT use supports for the locking pins or it will fill in the threaded receiver.

I've heard that the tolerances on the locking pins and launch pad top were a little tight, so I have posted a new launch pad top with a bit more room.
If you have an old one you can lightly sand the pins or the hole they slide through. That should solve the problem or you can download the launch pad top again.
-Best

I used two average sized rubber bands to hold the rocket together.
Because the bands were a little big I put one coiled twist in each of them to shrink the size by 50% and double the power.
Just reach up into the nose cone and put the bands over the hooks. be sure not to cross sides when attaching to the tail section hooks or it will interfere with the launch rod.

Finally, I tapped out the launcher pems and used 4/40 screws to hold the base together but I guess hot glue could work too.

All you need now is to just place a new pencil in the hole in the launcher and you are ready to go.
I used a yellow crayola pencil with some black electrical tape for deco on the rod.

comments.text: Great design!! Thank You! I highly recommend printing the bottom portion of the rocket upside down. On my printer I noticed it made for nicer hooks on the inside and fewer supports were needed. I'll add some pictures once the entire thing is completed.

description.text:
This is a newly (from ground) designed tool holder. But inspired by "Werkzeughalter". Like the original it is designed to fit on the top side of your Ultimaker printer. Unscrew two screws from the top side, and refit them while mounting the tool holder. The design perfectly fits the design of the Ultimaker printer.

The redesign is based on experience while using this tool holder. It holds (from top left, to bottom right):

  • Card (credit card size) for bed calibration purposes
  • Hex keys holders (4x) (open bottom)
  • Glue stick
  • SD cards (3x)
  • Box for mini sticking knife
  • Space for pliers (2 or 3) (open bottom)
  • Box for anything
  • Holders for screwdriver(s), oil tube, cleaning needles, spare nozzles, etc. (2x)
  • Holders (small) (2x) for screwdrivers, etc. (open bottom)
  • Holders (normal size) for pincet, screwdrivers, etc. (open bottom)

Any recommendations are welcome. Happy to make adjustments!

author: paglia

title: Eskrima Stick for Martial Arts Training

description.text:
This is an eskrima (escrima) stick you can print out and practice with. With 6 shells and 30% infill, the weight and feel will match a real rattan stick, but unfortunately, it will break after a few really hard hits. This is great for practicing forms, but probably not ideal for sparring. Blog entry on my first attempt:
http://theamazingdoctorawesome.blogspot.com/2014/03/3d-printing-eskrima-stick.html

Print out each end cap and twelve nodes using 6 shells and 30% infill.  If the fit is too tight or too loose, you can use some sandpaper, or adjust the "wiggle room" in the Eskrima_Stick.scad file.  
Glue the pieces together using acetone (assuming you print with ABS) and let it set.  
The weakest point of this design is actually not where you glued it together, but in-between the connections, where there is nothing but 30% infill pattern.  Higher infill percentages will be tougher, but they will be too heavy and lose the natural feel of a real eskrima stick.

title: Anet AM8 HD - heavy duty Anet A8 with 2040 welded metal frame - Prusa i3 clone

description.text:
I wanted a more sturdy printer because the acrylic frame of the anet a8 is not that stable, but i did not wanted to buy the alu profile since price is too high for my taste. I modified all the am8 parts in order to be able to mount all the support on smooth 2040 metal profile. Since making a hole in a precise place once the printer is welded is not that easdy because is hard to put in position,, i modified the parts in order to be slightly adjustable (+/- 1Cm of adjustement) so that you can precisely tune the position of rods for Y axis. All the other parts, if printer is properluy welded will fit precisely in position.

The Z upper support are made in order to satisfy wo like free rolling rod, and who like bearings on top. It already have space for 608zz bearings.

All the parts are modified from the original AM8 project. I've tried to go as similar as possible to the original prusa mk2 and i think i nailed it. I use Marlin 1.1.8, stock extruder and Slic3r prusa edition with prusa mk2 setting and accellerations and print perfectly....lowered stock Anet jerk to 10 as is on mk2. Even at 100mm linear advance setting print perfectly.

  • Adjustable feet to print in TPU lowered noise to sleep near to it level.

  • Mount your PSU and your mainboard out of the box or next to the printer, i do use https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2199806 since i have 2 psu now or you can put all in to a box with this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2536142

  • Welding in spot is not easy, in order to be perfectly squared down you need to create a mask that keep profile in place.

  • Z motor mount and upper Z mount have more hole than needed in order to adapt to thinner profile, in mine, i've put 3 screw in upper mount and 2 screw in motor mount and it is stuck, it will never move.

  • Use stainless steel auto perforating screw.

Anet a8

Yes

print_settings.Notes:: probably

title: Creality CR-10 Control Box 120mm Fan Mod

description.text:
IMPORTANT: READ THE END OF THIS FOR SAFETY INFORMATION.

Modification for the original Creality CR-10 control box; replaces the three loud fans inside with either one or two 120mm fans.

Print 2 of these stands and fit either one or both with 120mm fans (no screws required).

If you only fit one fan, I would recommend you fit the front stand with a fan blowing inwards so the air cools the power supply and goes up the box and cools both the circuit boards.

Open the control box, remove the power supply, open the power supply and snip the power cables to all three fans (or in the case of the power supply, unplug). Insulate any loose ends and remove the fans if you are not using them. Use the power cable from the front fan (the one cooling the main PCB) to power the 120mm fan. Sit the control box (sans the bottom) on the two stands and you are good to go.

Disclaimer: I have tried this cooling setup (one fan) printing PLA (210 degrees) with a 60 degree heated bed and everything works fine. I cannot guarantee that this would work if the printer is pushed to it's power limits as I have not tested it.

Other notes: To silence the hotend fan, one could use a separate power supply (or an appropriate resistor) to undervolt the fan instead of buying one of those expensive Noctua or Noiseblocker fans. I undervolted mine to around 6V with no problems (PLA 210 degrees). However do note that if the hotend fan does not push enough air, the PTFE tube will melt as the heatbreak will heat up too much, so make sure the fan pushes a reasonable amount of air whiles undervolting. To reiterate above, I shall not be responsible for bricked printers.

SAFETY:

TLDR: Do NOT lead the fan power wires out from the BACK area of the case where the high voltage wires are. Lead them out from the SIDE of the case OR even better use a separate power supply.

STORYTIME: I had used the power leads from the rear fan to power the 120mm fan, all was fine until I moved the printer. When I reconnected the printer and started printing, I realized that the 120mm fan was not working as the connection was a bit loose and had come off. As I fiddled with the wires (the control box was on it's side and the printer was printing; I did not want to disturb the print), the red wire slipped and touched one of the high voltage wire connections and the control box started SMOKING. I was very lucky that I was not touching the 12V red wire that got fried by 240V (I was still holding onto the black wire but God was kind).

In the end, everything was fine and I just lost the power cables to one fan (the rubber burnt off). Kudos to Creality for designing their PCBs to take some 240V interference and print fine afterwards. I dunno what to call this other than what Professor McGonagall would term 'sheer, dumb luck' but as they say, what does not kill you makes you smarter.

Learning Points:

  1. Try NOT to lead additional wires through areas where high voltage cables connect.
  2. Tie your wires properly, esp if they have a risk of touching bare connections.
  3. Remove or tie down any loose wires (e.g. from fans that you are not using) just so that there are less wires floating around
  4. Work with the mains power OFF (I admit this is me being supremely cocky fiddling with the control box when the printer is on) and check your work after to make sure no wires cross and stuff like that.

Happy modding guys & stay safe :)
